title: Rules for Meem Saakin
desc1_desc: When Meem Saakin (م) appears in Quranic recitation, one of the following three rules should be applied, depending on the letter that follows it:

sections.title: Idghaam Shafawee (إدغام شفوي)
sections.mean: This rule applies when Meem Saakin is followed by another Meem that has a vowel. Typically, the second Meem will have a Shaddah (ّ).
sections.how_to_pronounce: Merge the two Meems smoothly, using Ghunnah (a nasal sound) for 2-3 beats.

sections.title: Ikhfaa Shafawee (إخفاء شفوي)
sections.mean: This rule is applied when Meem Saakin is followed by the letter Ba (ب) with a vowel sound.
sections.how_to_pronounce: Conceal the sound of the Meem and pronounce it with Ghunnah for 2-3 beats.
sections.note: This rule is often overlooked, so pay special attention to ensure correct application.

sections.title: Izhaar Shafawee (إظهار شفوي)
sections.mean: Izhaar Shafawee occurs when Meem Saakin is followed by a letter other than Meem or Ba.
sections.how_to_pronounce: Clearly articulate the Meem without any nasalization (Ghunnah).

Quizs.question: What is the correct rule applied for Meem Saakin in the phrase تَرۡمِيۡهِم بِحِجَارَةٍ?

answers.answer: Ikhfa Shafawi: The Meem Saakin is followed by a Ba and is recited with a nasal sound.
Idgham Shafawi: The Meem Saakin merges into the next Meem.
Izhar Shafawi: The Meem Saakin is pronounced clearly without merging.
